Sign in Medium Logo Write Search Sign up Sign in Mastodon The Future of Leadership: Three Radical Truths Leaders Canâ€™t Ignore Samantha Truman 3 min read Â· Sep 22, 2025 -- Listen Share What Gallup, Edelman, and Deloitte data reveal about culture, trust, and retention in 2025 and beyond. M ost leaders wonâ€™t confront the reality that their behavior has the power to shape â€” or even destroy â€” lives. But Iâ€™ve lived it. Iâ€™ve seen it in my own family, and Iâ€™ve seen it in boardrooms. And itâ€™s why my leadership looks nothing like the traditional script. Corruption Up Close My first exposure to corruption wasnâ€™t in a company. It was in my biological father. Respected in his field, admired by many â€” and yet never held accountable. Power insulated him. Power fed his abuse. Press enter or click to view image in full size Samantha Truman in her fatherâ€™s glasses thinking about the world he helped shape and damage. I learned early that one small abuse of power grows until it becomes a system. Later, in boardrooms, I saw it again. Leaders covering for one another. Whistleblowers punished. Retaliation. Psychological bullying. Careers destroyed. What struck me most? Poor leadership didnâ€™t just cost jobs. It cost health. Dignity. Sometimes life itself. And this isnâ€™t isolated. Gallup (2023): Only 27% of managers globally are engaged â€” and disengaged managers poison entire teams. Edelman Trust Barometer (2024): 63% of people trust their employer more than government, media, or NGOs. Leaders arenâ€™t just running companies â€” theyâ€™re on the frontline of trust in society. Fail inside your workplace, and you fail the cultural contract at large. The Three Radical Truths Your treatment of people dictates their trajectory. A promotion, a dismissal, a word of encouragement â€” it can change the course of a life. Thereâ€™s no such thing as a perfect leader. The only ones worth following are those willing to adapt, flex, and keep learning. Leadership can be fun. Youâ€™re in the business of inspiring people. Thatâ€™s not just pressure, itâ€™s power. The Future of Leadership The next generation is watching. Gen Z and Millennials are not just the workforce of tomorrow, they are already reshaping todayâ€™s workplace expectations. Two out of three plan to leave their jobs by 2030 if their leaders donâ€™t reflect their values (Deloitte Gen Z & Millennial Survey, 2024). Retention wonâ€™t be a loyalty game anymore. It will be a cultural health game. Radical leadership means asking yourself every day: ðŸ‘‰ Am I protecting my position, or am I shaping someoneâ€™s life for the better? The difference could define the future of work. And weâ€™re already watching the cost of low-accountability leadership play out on the biggest stage: politics. The same patterns that corrode workplaces â€” leaders dodging responsibility, spinning half-truths, protecting power at the expense of people â€” show up in how political leaders govern and how thought leaders posture. The result is the same: fractured trust, fragile systems, and disillusioned people. Press enter or click to view image in full size Photo by Samantha Sophia on Unsplash The stakes are too high to believe that weak accountability will somehow create stronger organizations, healthier democracies, or better systems. It wonâ€™t. If anything, it accelerates collapse. The future of leadership isnâ€™t just a workplace issue. Itâ€™s a governance issue. Itâ€™s a democracy issue. Itâ€™s a trust issue. The cost of getting it wrong isnâ€™t just failed companies â€” itâ€™s broken systems and broken lives. We should lead with courage, clarity, and care â€” not as a performance, but as a daily practice that protects people, strengthens culture, and builds systems that last. Iâ€™m building a global conversation on cultural health, leadership, and the future of work. Follow me here and on Substack for more essays, data, and strategies on how we build workplaces â€” and leaders â€” that last. Radical leadership means asking yourself every day: ðŸ‘‰ Am I protecting my position, or am I shaping someoneâ€™s life for the better?","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":133,"end":208,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:66aea430ab2c_18":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"66aea430ab2c_18","name":"f1ae","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The difference could define the future of work.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:66aea430ab2c_19":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"66aea430ab2c_19","name":"a3b7","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"And weâ€™re already watching the cost of low-accountability leadership play out on the biggest stage: politics. The same patterns that corrode workplaces â€” leaders dodging responsibility, spinning half-truths, protecting power at the expense of people â€” show up in how political leaders govern and how thought leaders posture. The result is the same: fractured trust, fragile systems, and disillusioned people.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:0*aoDhayrPUGUivM1V":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"0*aoDhayrPUGUivM1V","originalHeight":3456,"originalWidth":5184,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:66aea430ab2c_20":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"66aea430ab2c_20","name":"1f96","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:0*aoDhayrPUGUivM1V"},"text":"Photo by Samantha Sophia on Unsplash","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"A","start":9,"end":24,"href":"https:\u002F\u002Funsplash.com\u002F@samanthasophia?utm_source=medium&utm_medium=referral","anchorType":"LINK","userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"A","start":28,"end":36,"href":"https:\u002F\u002Funsplash.com?utm_source=medium&utm_medium=referral","anchorType":"LINK","userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:66aea430ab2c_21":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"66aea430ab2c_21","name":"1d2f","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The stakes are too high to believe that weak accountability will somehow create stronger organizations, healthier democracies, or better systems. It wonâ€™t. If anything, it accelerates collapse.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:66aea430ab2c_22":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"66aea430ab2c_22","name":"2ec4","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The future of leadership isnâ€™t just a workplace issue. Itâ€™s a governance issue. Itâ€™s a democracy issue. Itâ€™s a trust issue. The cost of getting it wrong isnâ€™t just failed companies â€” itâ€™s broken systems and broken lives.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:66aea430ab2c_23":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"66aea430ab2c_23","name":"590f","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"We should lead with courage, clarity, and care â€” not as a performance, but as a daily practice that protects people, strengthens culture, and builds systems that last.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:66aea430ab2c_24":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"66aea430ab2c_24","name":"676b","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Iâ€™m building a global conversation on cultural health, leadership, and the future of work. your culture â€” or your bottom line. The Great Obsession Return to office has become the fixation of executives everywhere. Three days, four days, hybrid policies, badge swipes â€” itâ€™s treated like the cure-all for broken culture and declining performance. But hereâ€™s the problem: return to office is not a fix. Itâ€™s a distraction. Press enter or click to view image in full size What RTO Doesnâ€™t Solve The real issues plaguing organizations â€” burnout, disengagement, lack of trust, inequitable systems â€” donâ€™t vanish just because people are back in cubicles. In fact, for many, the commute, rigid schedules, and loss of autonomy make it worse. Gallupâ€™s State of the Workplace (2025): Only 23% of employees worldwide are engaged. In the U.S., just 32%. MIT Sloan research: Toxic culture is 10.4x more predictive of attrition than pay. Stanford study: Remote workers are 13% more productive thanks to fewer interruptions. The data is clear: dragging people back into the office doesnâ€™t heal disengagement â€” it accelerates resentment. Productivity Myths vs. Reality Leaders like to frame RTO as a productivity play. The evidence doesnâ€™t support it. Global four-day workweek pilots: Productivity gains + 69% lower burnout, 42% better mental health, 37% better physical health. UK trial: Turnover cut by 39%, saving employers millions. Microsoft Japan: 40% increase in productivity during their four-day trial. The truth: flexibility and trust drive results. Mandates donâ€™t. Press enter or click to view image in full size Why Leaders Cling to RTO Return to office feels tangible. You can mandate policies. You can count badge swipes. You can see people in chairs. It creates the illusion of alignment. But alignment doesnâ€™t live in chairs. Alignment lives in: Trust Clarity Accountability Systems that support human beings The Real Rupture The rupture is not remote work. The rupture is cultural health. The rupture is leadership that hasnâ€™t adapted to the realities of human systems in a post-pandemic world. If you want performance, donâ€™t drag people back into outdated models. Build systems that are: Flexible Equitable Breathable Designed for autonomy and accountability Final Word Return to office is a false fix. Itâ€™s duct tape over a cracked foundation. The real work is much harder â€” and much more urgent. Because the organizations that invest in cultural health now wonâ€™t just retain talent. Theyâ€™ll define the future of work. ðŸ’¡ Culture isnâ€™t a side project â€” itâ€™s the infrastructure of performance. ðŸ‘‰ If youâ€™re ready to assess the health of your culture and build systems that actually work, explore the CultureShift Diagnosticâ„¢ or connect with me here on LinkedIn . Sign in Medium Logo Write Search Sign up Sign in Mastodon Culture Will Collapse Companies Before AI Does Samantha Truman 6 min read Â· Sep 9, 2025 -- Listen Share By 2030, artificial intelligence wonâ€™t be the reason most companies fail. Culture will. Yes, AI is accelerating at a pace we can barely process. Yes, automation will reshape industries, workflows, and entire professions. But the truth is this: technology has never been the bottleneck. Culture has. Organizations donâ€™t fall apart because the tools werenâ€™t powerful enough. They fall apart because their people were too burned out, too silenced, too mistrustful to commit to change. Unless leaders confront this now, AI will not save them. It will speed up their demise. And underneath it all is one question we donâ€™t ask enough: What happens when curiosity goes missing? Three Lenses on Culture Iâ€™ve lived this question in my body, in my work, and in my consulting practice. Each story is a different vantage point into culture: The Body â€” as a patient ignored until my heart stopped beating. The Chart â€” as a consultant watching bias calcify into medical â€œtruth.â€ The Office â€” as an employee hardened by toxicity until walking through the door felt impossible. Three perspectives. Same truth. Culture left unexamined doesnâ€™t just hurt people. It kills trust. It kills possibility. Sometimes, it kills people. The Body It was a crisp spring day in Texas, 2021. I left the hospital with my precious newborn and a blood pressure of 170/130. One week after giving birth, my feet were swollen to 2x their normal size. My body hit its breaking point. I called my doctors again and again. They told me: â€œDonâ€™t worry. Itâ€™s fine.â€ It wasnâ€™t fine. Press enter or click to view image in full size Two hands intertwined: one just beginning, one fighting to stay. A year later, I walked into the ER well after midnight. The hallways were cold. The sterile smell flooded the air. My fingers in my left hand had gone numb, my chest was tightening. My blood pressure read 233/155. The physician, eyes agape said, â€œYouâ€™re a dead woman walking.â€ Within 48 hours, I flatlined. My heart stopped in the car. With keen consciousness I heard her shaken voice repeating my name. It was my mother next to me. She repeated my name and her words became more distant. But I couldnâ€™t respond. All I could see was this: my lifeâ€™s most beautiful memories, and my time running out. Hereâ€™s the truth I canâ€™t sugarcoat; I wasnâ€™t uninformed. I was a consultant in the health equity space at the time. I knew the data then, and I know it now. In 2023, the CDC reported that Black women are roughly three times more likely to die from pregnancy-related causes. So no â€” it wasnâ€™t fine. I knew all of it, and still, I almost died. Because knowing isnâ€™t the same as being believed. And none of the people who met me in those hospitals were curious enough to ask deeper questions. This is what happens when institutional culture erases the patientâ€™s full experience. The Chart Months later, I investigated culturally responsive care at a hospital in the Southwest. During a session with Emergency Medicine physicians, I learned of an Indigenous man with cirrhosis who had been branded â€œalcoholicâ€ in his chart for over a decade. A label that followed him through every encounter. The truth? He had never taken a single drink. After years of assumption, one physician finally broke the pattern: â€œWe have so many treatments that could help you. Could you share a little more about your relationship with alcohol?â€ Press enter or click to view image in full size Every page tells a story â€” but what happens when the story is wrong? Soon a decade-long lie unraveled. Ten years of being denied treatment, medications, and clinical trials. Just because he was an Indigenous man? This wasnâ€™t an outlier. In listening sessions, physicians told story after story of bias calcifying into treatment decisions. They knew it was wrong, but they also knew it was normal. Bias isnâ€™t just personal prejudice. Itâ€™s systemic. It gets taught, reinforced, repeated, until lies become medical fact. And without curiosity, bias becomes truth on paper. When truth dies, people die with it. This is what happens when institutional culture normalizes assumption over inquiry. The Office Years before, I sat in my car outside the office â€” dressed, makeup on â€” unable to walk through the doors. On the outside, I looked polished. On the inside, I was numb. My hands tapped against the steering wheel, no clear exit in sight. Press enter or click to view image in full size This is what happens when psychological safety disappears. Thatâ€™s what toxic workplaces do: they harden you until you canâ€™t feel, your body stuck in permanent flight mode. I knew if I walked in, one more comment would unravel me. So I stayed in the car. Shaken. Picked up the phone. Called in sick. And drove home. People call disengagement laziness. Itâ€™s not. Itâ€™s survival. And itâ€™s expensive. MIT Sloan found toxic culture is the #1 predictor of attrition â€” 10x more than pay . Gallup estimates disengagement costs the global economy $8.8 trillion annually â€” 9% of GDP . When psychological safety is missing, curiosity dies. No one asks, â€œHow are you really?â€ No one asks, â€œWhat would make this better?â€ This is what happens when workplace culture silences until numbness feels safer than showing up. The Framework Emerges Across these stories â€” my body, the chart, the office â€” I saw the same truth: culture either suffocates or sustains. Thatâ€™s why I built the Cultural Health Frameworkâ„¢ , naming the five dimensions where curiosity either thrives or disappears: Press enter or click to view image in full size See visual breakdown of the Cultural Health Frameworkâ„¢, my proprietary model developed at True People Consulting. I created the Cultural Health Frameworkâ„¢ because I wanted leaders and institutions to see cultural health as holistic â€” woven across institutional practices, individual experiences, and interpersonal relationships â€” where each dimension feeds the other, so that institutions sustain their people, and people, in turn, sustain the institution. These arenâ€™t soft skills. They are the architecture of cultural health. The 2030 Window By 2030, AI could automate up to three hours of daily work per employee (McKinsey, 2023). Thatâ€™s not just efficiency. Thatâ€™s freedom. Freedom to focus on creativity, strategy, problem-solving. Freedom to build workplaces worth entering. But hereâ€™s the problem: 54% of early-career employees say AI access would influence their job choice (Deloitte, 2024). Only 22% of organizations say theyâ€™re culturally ready for AI adoption (PwC, 2024). The question isnâ€™t whether AI will transform your company. It will. If we canâ€™t even get culture right now â€” when weâ€™re operating on analog systems, with all the tools we already have â€” why do we think AI will suddenly make us better? It wonâ€™t. It will multiply whatâ€™s already there. If culture is broken, AI will scale the harm. If culture is healthy, AI will amplify that health. This isnâ€™t about rejecting AI. Itâ€™s about recognizing what it reveals. AI is a mirror. It reflects â€” and accelerates â€” the culture we already have. What happens when curiosity dies? Iâ€™ve lived this â€” in my own body, as a consultant, and as an employee. Culture isnâ€™t a vibe. Itâ€™s infrastructure. This is the time to lean into curiosity and pay attention to our cultural health. Weâ€™re not facing a workplace apocalypse. Weâ€™re standing at the threshold of a Workplace Renaissance . title:
Perfect! That's exactly what I do. Let me ask you a couple things so I find the *right* leads for you.

**Who are you looking for?** Just give me the job title or role to startâ€”like "VP of Sales," "CTOs," "Marketing Directors," whatever makes sense for your business.
content: 50 ciso's from the usa

title:
I can definitely help you craft outreach for fintech CFOs! But for the actual messaging and sequences, let's do that in the **Campaign Hub** where you can customize, preview, and manage everything properly.

Before you head there thoughâ€”I want to make sure your campaigns hit hard. I noticed your Knowledge Base is pretty light right now (15% complete). The more I know about your business, the better your fintech CFO messaging will be. Want to spend a few minutes filling in the gaps first, or jump straight to Campaign Hub and we'll refine as we go?
content: Campaign hub

Sign in Medium Logo Write Search Sign up Sign in Mastodon The Workplace Renaissance: Why 2030 Will Redefine Work and Leadership Samantha Truman 4 min read Â· Aug 21, 2025 -- Listen Share I once sat in my car, fully dressed for work, and couldnâ€™t make myself walk through the office doors. Years later, I nearly lost my life after childbirth â€” not because of medical complexity, but because of a broken system that treated human beings as expendable. Press enter or click to view image in full size Samantha Truman, with her 6-week-old newborn in 2021, unaware that pre-eclampsia would soon lead to serious health complications. Those moments taught me something Iâ€™ve carried into every boardroom and consulting engagement since: the health of our culture determines whether we thrive, or collapse. Now, standing at the edge of 2030, I believe weâ€™re entering a Workplace Renaissance â€” a moment as consequential as the European Renaissance centuries ago. But this time, whatâ€™s at stake isnâ€™t art or science. Itâ€™s whether the systems we spend most of our waking lives inside will sustain usâ€¦ or destroy us. The Problem: Cruel Work If your workplace leaves you whispering â€œthank God itâ€™s Friday,â€ something is deeply wrong. If leaders confuse fear for motivation, or metrics for meaning, they build what I call cruel work : systems that drain energy, flatten creativity, and break trust. We see the fallout everywhere: Burnout has been declared a workplace epidemic (World Health Organization). Gallup finds that 60% of people feel emotionally detached from work â€” and 19% are miserable at work every day. The U.S. Surgeon General has called for treating workplace wellbeing as a public health priority. Fear-led leadership can produce short-term compliance. But long-term, it corrodes trust and sends your best people walking. The younger generations especially â€” Millennials and Gen Z â€” will simply leave. Or theyâ€™ll reject the system altogether and build something new. Why a Renaissance, and Why Now? The Renaissance of the 15th century was born out of the collapse of the Dark Ages. People had endured plague, corruption, and stagnation. They were desperate for light, truth, beauty, and possibility. The printing press democratized knowledge. New patrons supported art and science. Curiosity flourished. Press enter or click to view image in full size The Citizens of Tournai, Belgium, Burying the Dead During the Black Death of 1347â€“1352 from Chronicles of Gilles Li Muisis (1272â€“1352) , Abbot of the Monastery of St. Martin of the Righteous, f. 24v., Royal Library of Belgium, Brussels, Belgium. We are standing in a parallel moment. After a pandemic that forced billions of people to rethink life and work, a similar hunger has emerged. Weâ€™ve tasted freedom. Weâ€™ve glimpsed alternatives. And now, many refuse to go back. Three forces are converging to drive this 2030 Workplace Renaissance : Technology & Innovation AI, automation, and creator platforms are our version of the printing press. Knowledge, skills, and tools are democratized. Almost anyone can learn, build, and reach a global audience. The gatekeepers are losing their grip. Political & Cultural Upheaval Just as city-states of Renaissance Italy were marked by turbulence and conflict, our current world is polarized, unstable, and ripe for reformation. Trust in institutions is low â€” but that pressure is forcing reinvention. Post-Pandemic Memory The pandemic was our plague: devastating, disruptive, and clarifying. For the first time, millions saw that work could be flexible, human, and life-giving. That memory wonâ€™t fade. It planted seeds of rebellion against â€œcruel work.â€ The Human Hunger Driving It This Renaissance isnâ€™t just about technology or economics. Itâ€™s about human longing. People today are seeking: Meaning: Search data shows â€œpurposeâ€ and â€œsuccessâ€ an increase Googled terms globally. Freedom: Gen Z is walking away from rigid careers and inventing new ways to sustain themselves in the creator economy. Self-Actualization: From TikTok to Reddit, people are asking existential questions about identity, spirituality, and fulfillment. This is a cultural hunger we havenâ€™t seen in centuries. Work is becoming not just about paychecks but about psychological safety, dignity, and hope. Whatâ€™s Newly Possible (2025â€“2030) What makes this moment unprecedented isnâ€™t just hunger â€” itâ€™s access. Open Skill Markets: Platforms, AI tutors, and global networks mean you can acquire skills once reserved for elite institutions. Creator Patronage: In the Renaissance, artists needed patrons like the Medici. Today, the creator economy and digital platforms act as modern patronage systems. Cultural Intelligence Tools: We now have the ability to measure and track cultural health in real time. At True People Consulting, our CultureShift Diagnosticâ„¢ and PulseOpsâ„¢ system function like a printing press for culture itself â€” making invisible dynamics visible, and change possible. The Non-Negotiables of a Renaissance Workplace Renaissance-ready organizations wonâ€™t be built on perks, ping-pong tables, or slogans. They will be built on: Psychological Safety The single strongest predictor of team performance (Googleâ€™s Project Aristotle). Teams with near-perfect safety scores can achieve results that feel almost impossible. Trust as Infrastructure Not vibes, but systems that institutionalize fairness, accountability, and voice. Time Autonomy Flexibility is no longer a perk â€” itâ€™s a prerequisite for sustained creativity and health. Learning Posture in Leadership Leaders who are future-forward, curious, and human-centered. Those clinging to authority for control will lead their organizations straight into irrelevance. The Stakes If leaders ignore this moment, they risk becoming relics of the Dark Ages. Trust will fracture. Talent will leave. AI will amplify cultural rot instead of solving it. But if leaders embrace it, they have the chance to create organizations that are not just efficient, but truly alive â€” workplaces that multiply creativity, resilience, and human potential. Naming the Moment Iâ€™m calling this the 2030 Workplace Renaissance. Because history is repeating itself in new form. Just as the Renaissance birthed humanism, exploration, and artistic genius, this moment can birth workplaces that sustain human dignity, creativity, and collective flourishing. The choice is simple: cling to the Dark Ages of cruel work, or join the Renaissance. Leaders who wait will miss it. Leaders who see the Renaissance unfolding will shape it. Follow me on LinkedIn for practical insights, and on Substack for deeper essays. Donâ€™t just watch history â€” help write it. When Silence Speaks: How Cracked Culture Destroys Psychological Safety at Work Fear, whispers, and unspoken tension arenâ€™t minor issuesâ€”theyâ€™re the cracks that erode trust, flatten performance, and make even the brightest teams burn out. Samantha Truman Sep 18, 2025 1 Share You can feel when culture is cracked. That weird silence. The whispers never spoken. The air thick. You knowâ€”before words appearâ€”that something has shifted. At a Big Five consulting firm, I stood by the beverage stationâ€”just observing. I wasnâ€™t even introduced yet; still, a leader approached me with sharpness that cut through the room. Later, introductions were made, and the room changed tone. Pin-drop quiet. Was it my accent, my hair, the way I smelled? Who knows. But it was a rupture. Once, in a tech company, staff had their own nickname for leadership: â€œthe Catholic Church.â€ Because executive kept harassing the staffâ€”and instead of intervening, they moved him around. Nobody spoke up. They hid the problem under schedule shuffles and HR â€œhandles.â€ Thatâ€™s when values on the wall become meaningless; the question becomes: â€œIf youâ€™re protecting power over people, do your values even matter?â€ Silence calcifies into culture. The Catholic Church reference captures something we see in many institutions: silence becomes the system. When harm surfaces, the instinct isnâ€™t accountabilityâ€”itâ€™s containment. Protect the leader. Move the problem. Keep the machine running. The tragedy? In protecting power, we destroy trust. Most workplaces wonâ€™t make front-page headlines like the Church. But when whispers replace truth, when harm is minimized or buried, the damage is just as real. We recoil at what happened in the Churchâ€”but how different is it, really, when companies use silence as strategy? Thanks for reading The Culture Room! This post is public so feel free to share it. Share Work becomes survival. Maslowâ€™s hierarchy doesnâ€™t list values; it lists safety, food, belonging . People would rather protect their rent checks than uphold the truth. And employees? They feel the weight of silence. They wonder: â€œAm I safe enough to be honest?â€ Short answer: No. The result is a cratering of psychological safetyâ€”fear, apathy, burnout. Performance doesnâ€™t just dip. It flatlines. Iâ€™ve seen teams where communication was so fractured we had to start with nonviolent communication workshops â€”just so people could talk without fear. Thatâ€™s not HR fluff. Thatâ€™s triage. The Recovery Path Investigation â€“ I listen. Leaders, mid-level, new hiresâ€”I gather every cornerâ€™s story. Truth â€“ Bring whatâ€™s hidden into daylight, even if it shakes foundations. Clarity â€“ Build a roadmap thatâ€™s not aspirational, but actionable. Repair â€“ Workshops, retreats, reset sessions, facilitation. Strategically applied, fiercely human. Thanks for reading The Culture Room! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Subscribe The Radical Truth Toxic culture is far worse than a few missing perks. Because people will trade money for peace. Iâ€™ve watched brilliant people take lower pay just to have dignity at work. Culture that breaks doesnâ€™t have to be the end. It can be the beginning of repairâ€”if you face it, name it, and build again. Closing Call If this resonates, stay with me here on Substack. whispers, and unspoken tension aren\u2019t minor issues\u2014they\u2019re the cracks that erode trust, flatten performance, and make even the brightest teams burn out.\",\"teaser_post_eligible\":true,\"title\":\"When Silence Speaks: How Cracked Culture Destroys Psychological Safety at Work\",\"type\":\"newsletter\",\"video_upload_id\":null,\"write_comment_permissions\":\"everyone\",\"meter_type\":\"none\",\"live_stream_id\":null,\"is_published\":true,\"restacks\":1,\"reactions\":{\"\u2764\":0},\"top_exclusions\":[],\"pins\":[],\"section_pins\":[],\"has_shareable_clips\":false,\"previous_post_slug\":\"ai-isnt-the-future-of-work-we-are\",\"next_post_slug\":\"the-5-pillars-of-cultural-health\",\"cover_image\":\"https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!4reC!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fb9aed5f2-82ac-44c6-85ab-afe074cfae49_5760x3264.jpeg\",\"cover_image_is_square\":false,\"cover_image_is_explicit\":false,\"videoUpload\":null,\"podcastFields\":{\"post_id\":173946465,\"podcast_episode_number\":null,\"podcast_season_number\":null,\"podcast_episode_type\":null,\"should_syndicate_to_other_feed\":null,\"syndicate_to_section_id\":null,\"hide_from_feed\":false,\"free_podcast_url\":null,\"free_podcast_duration\":null},\"podcastUpload\":null,\"podcastPreviewUpload\":null,\"voiceover_upload_id\":null,\"voiceoverUpload\":null,\"has_voiceover\":false,\"description\":\"Fear, whispers, and unspoken tension aren\u2019t minor issues\u2014they\u2019re the cracks that erode trust, flatten performance, and make even the brightest teams burn out.\",\"body_html\":\" You can feel when culture is cracked. That weird silence. The whispers never spoken. The air thick. You know\u2014before words appear\u2014that something has shifted. At a Big Five consulting firm, I stood by the beverage station\u2014just observing. I wasn\u2019t even introduced yet; still, a leader approached me with sharpness that cut through the room. Later, introductions were made, and the room changed tone. Pin-drop quiet. Was it my accent, my hair, the way I smelled? Who knows. But it was a rupture. Once, in a tech company, staff had their own nickname for leadership: \u201Cthe Catholic Church.\u201D Because executive kept harassing the staff\u2014and instead of intervening, they moved him around. Nobody spoke up. They hid the problem under schedule shuffles and HR \u201Chandles.\u201D That\u2019s when values on the wall become meaningless; the question becomes: \u201CIf you\u2019re protecting power over people, do your values even matter?\u201D Silence calcifies into culture. The Catholic Church reference captures something we see in many institutions: silence becomes the system. When harm surfaces, the instinct isn\u2019t accountability\u2014it\u2019s containment. Protect the leader. Move the problem. Keep the machine running. The tragedy? In protecting power, we destroy trust. Most workplaces won\u2019t make front-page headlines like the Church. But when whispers replace truth, when harm is minimized or buried, the damage is just as real. We recoil at what happened in the Church\u2014but how different is it, really, when companies use silence as strategy? Thanks for reading The Culture Room! This post is public so feel free to share it. Share Work becomes survival. Maslow\u2019s hierarchy doesn\u2019t list values; it lists safety, food, belonging . People would rather protect their rent checks than uphold the truth. And employees? They feel the weight of silence. They wonder: \u201CAm I safe enough to be honest?\u201D Short answer: No. The result is a cratering of psychological safety\u2014fear, apathy, burnout. Performance doesn\u2019t just dip. It flatlines. I\u2019ve seen teams where communication was so fractured we had to start with nonviolent communication workshops \u2014just so people could talk without fear. That\u2019s not HR fluff. That\u2019s triage. The Recovery Path Investigation \u2013 I listen. Leaders, mid-level, new hires\u2014I gather every corner\u2019s story. Truth \u2013 Bring what\u2019s hidden into daylight, even if it shakes foundations. Clarity \u2013 Build a roadmap that\u2019s not aspirational, but actionable. Repair \u2013 Workshops, retreats, reset sessions, facilitation. Strategically applied, fiercely human. Thanks for reading The Culture Room! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. The Radical Truth Toxic culture is far worse than a few missing perks. Because people will trade money for peace. I\u2019ve watched brilliant people take lower pay just to have dignity at work. Culture that breaks doesn\u2019t have to be the end. It can be the beginning of repair\u2014if you face it, name it, and build again. Closing Call If this resonates, stay with me here on Substack. I write for leaders who know culture isn\u2019t HR\u2019s side project\u2014it\u2019s the infrastructure that decides whether people thrive or collapse. \uD83D\uDC49 Subscribe for future essays or connect with me on LinkedIn if you\u2019re building a workplace where truth and trust actually matter. \",\"truncated_body_text\":\"You can feel when culture is Love + Leadership: Why the Strongest Leaders Lead with Care and Accountability Samantha Truman Sep 26, 2025 Share Iâ€™ve been analyzing the relationship between love and leadership â€” two words that rarely show up in the same sentence, but that define every leader I respect. Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve found: love isnâ€™t soft. Itâ€™s strategic. It builds resilience, trust, and loyalty in ways fear or control never can. Below are five lessons â€” tested in the field, backed by research, and deeply human. Photo by Sigmund on Unsplash 1. Love Means Telling the Truth (Even When It Hurts) Hard conversations are the sharp edge of leadership. Naming a misstep, calling out a pattern, practicing accountability â€” these donâ€™t always feel like love. But they are. Love without truth is enabling. Truth without love is cruelty. Leaders need both. ðŸ“Š Research check : Studies on authentic leadership show honesty and transparency are top drivers of trust (Walumbwa et al., 2008). Teams with candid leaders are 40% more likely to commit long-term. 2. Care Is Not Coddling â€” Itâ€™s Accountability Some leaders think care means lowering the bar. But real care raises the bar and coaches people toward it. Care is believing someone can grow â€” and walking with them until they do. ðŸ“Š Research check : Gallup found that managers who combine high expectations with active support double the odds of engagement compared to those who only â€œsupportâ€ or only â€œdemand.â€ Thanks for reading The Culture Room! This post is public so feel free to share it. Share 3. Love Builds Psychological Safety Teams donâ€™t innovate if theyâ€™re scared. Period. Love, expressed through empathy and presence, creates the safety net people need to take risks. ðŸ“Š Research check : Googleâ€™s Project Aristotle identified psychological safety as the #1 predictor of high-performing teams. When leaders model compassion, error-reporting goes up â€” and so does innovation. 4. Love Means Knowing Your Limits Leadership is not martyrdom. Iâ€™ve had to learn to name where I need support, to be transparent about my limits, to stay in a learning posture. That honesty creates trust â€” and models healthy boundaries for the team. ðŸ“Š Research check : Studies on compassion fatigue show leaders who set boundaries reduce burnout for both themselves and their teams (SeppÃ¤lÃ¤ et al., Stanford). 5. The Soul of Strategy Is Human-Centered Every KPI, roadmap, and policy should feed human beings â€” not strip them down. Love in leadership asks: How will this strategy impact the people who carry it out? If the answer is â€œwith harm,â€ itâ€™s not strategy. Itâ€™s extraction. ðŸ“Š Research check : Deloitteâ€™s 2023 Human Capital Trends report found that orgs prioritizing human outcomes + business outcomes were 2.2x more likely to achieve long-term success. If you want loyalty, innovation, and performance that lasts, lead with love. Itâ€™s not soft. been analyzing the relationship between love and leadership \u2014 two words that rarely show up in the same sentence, but that define every leader I respect.\",\"body_html\":\" I\u2019ve been analyzing the relationship between love and leadership \u2014 two words that rarely show up in the same sentence, but that define every leader I respect. Here\u2019s what I\u2019ve found: love isn\u2019t soft. It\u2019s strategic. It builds resilience, trust, and loyalty in ways fear or control never can. Below are five lessons \u2014 tested in the field, backed by research, and deeply human. Photo by Sigmund on Unsplash 1. Love Means Telling the Truth (Even When It Hurts) Hard conversations are the sharp edge of leadership. Naming a misstep, calling out a pattern, practicing accountability \u2014 these don\u2019t always feel like love. But they are. Love without truth is enabling. Truth without love is cruelty. Leaders need both. \uD83D\uDCCA Research check : Studies on authentic leadership show honesty and transparency are top drivers of trust (Walumbwa et al., 2008). Teams with candid leaders are 40% more likely to commit long-term. 2. Care Is Not Coddling \u2014 It\u2019s Accountability Some leaders think care means lowering the bar. But real care raises the bar and coaches people toward it. Care is believing someone can grow \u2014 and walking with them until they do. \uD83D\uDCCA Research check : Gallup found that managers who combine high expectations with active support double the odds of engagement compared to those who only \u201Csupport\u201D or only \u201Cdemand.\u201D Thanks for reading The Culture Room! This post is public so feel free to share it. Share 3. Love Builds Psychological Safety Teams don\u2019t innovate if they\u2019re scared. Period. Love, expressed through empathy and presence, creates the safety net people need to take risks. \uD83D\uDCCA Research check : Google\u2019s Project Aristotle identified psychological safety as the #1 predictor of high-performing teams. When leaders model compassion, error-reporting goes up \u2014 and so does innovation. 4. Love Means Knowing Your Limits Leadership is not martyrdom. I\u2019ve had to learn to name where I need support, to be transparent about my limits, to stay in a learning posture. That honesty creates trust \u2014 and models healthy boundaries for the team. \uD83D\uDCCA Research check : Studies on compassion fatigue show leaders who set boundaries reduce burnout for both themselves and their teams (Sepp\u00E4l\u00E4 et al., Stanford). 5. The Soul of Strategy Is Human-Centered Every KPI, roadmap, and policy should feed human beings \u2014 not strip them down. Love in leadership asks: How will this strategy impact the people who carry it out? If the answer is \u201Cwith harm,\u201D it\u2019s not strategy. It\u2019s extraction. \uD83D\uDCCA Research check : Deloitte\u2019s 2023 Human Capital Trends report found that orgs prioritizing human outcomes + business outcomes were 2.2x more likely to achieve long-term success. Thanks for reading The Culture Room! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. \uD83D\uDCA1 Takeaway Fear burns fast \u2014 and burns people out. Love sustains. If you want loyalty, innovation, and performance that lasts, lead with love. It\u2019s not soft. It\u2019s the strongest strategy you have. \uD83D\uDD14 Subscribe for cultural strategy insights \u2764\uFE0F Like & share if you want leaders to hear this \uD83D\uDCE9 DM me to learn more about my Maven course: Culture & Strategy Lab: Future-Ready Leadership for the 2030 Workforce: https://maven.com/samanthatruman/culture-strategy-lab \",\"truncated_body_text\":\"I\u2019ve been analyzing the relationship between love and leadership \u2014 two words that rarely show up in the same sentence, but that define every leader I respect.\",\"wordcount\":514,\"postTags\":[],\"postCountryBlocks\":[],\"headlineTest\":null,\"coverImagePalette\":{\"Vibrant\":{\"rgb\":[153.35664335664336,126.6083916083916,101.64335664335663],\"population\":0},\"DarkVibrant\":{\"rgb\":[79.74545454545456,65.83636363636363,52.85454545454544],\"population\":0},\"LightVibrant\":{\"rgb\":[202.14545454545456,188.23636363636362,175.25454545454545],\"population\":0},\"Muted\":{\"rgb\":[143,121,104],\"population\":86},\"DarkMuted\":{\"rgb\":[78,67,61],\"population\":119},\"LightMuted\":{\"rgb\":[198,183,169],\"population\":148}},\"publishedBylines\":[{\"id\":354575259,\"name\":\"Samantha Truman\",\"handle\":\"samanthatruman\",\"previous_name\":null,\"photo_url\":\"https://substack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/images/4ad15820-cb12-4873-9435-bdbd99ae9732_1175x1177.jpeg\",\"bio\":\"I write about culture, leadership, and the future of work. Naming what\u2019s broken, building what\u2019s next \u2014 and inviting you to join me. Check out the social links to learn more about this work. Open in app Sign up Sign in Medium Logo Write Search Sign up Sign in Mastodon AI Wonâ€™t Save Work â€” Humans Will: The Culture Strategy Leaders Are Missing Samantha Truman 4 min read Â· Sep 1, 2025 -- 1 Listen Share Executives love silver bullets. And right now, the shiniest one is AI. From boardrooms to Slack threads, leaders are asking: How do we use AI to cut costs, boost productivity, and stay ahead? Hereâ€™s the hard truth: AI wonâ€™t save work. Humans will. AI is a tool, not a strategy. And culture, not code, will decide who thrives in the next decade. Press enter or click to view image in full size A human hand reaching out toward an illuminated digital interface, symbolizing the connection between people and AI technology. The Current State of Work Letâ€™s start where we are: Disengagement is bleeding companies dry. Gallup estimates that disengaged employees cost the global economy $8.8 trillion annually â€” 9% of global GDP . In the U.S., only 32% of employees are engaged , while the rest are emotionally detached or actively disengaged. Thatâ€™s not a future-of-work problem. Thatâ€™s a today problem. Turnover is expensive. Replacing a single employee can cost anywhere from 50% to 200% of their annual salary , once you factor in recruitment, training, and the morale dip of losing strong talent. Burnout isnâ€™t anecdotal anymore. In a global four-day workweek trial, 69% of participants reported reduced burnout, 42% better mental health, and 37% improved physical health . Productivity also improved in several sectors. Translation: better systems improve human performance. So before we chase shiny tech, leaders need to admit: the cracks are already here. The Misread of AI When leaders talk about AI, I hear two tones. One is fear â€” â€œItâ€™s coming for our jobs.â€ The other is greed â€” â€œWe can finally slash staffing.â€ Both miss the point. AI isnâ€™t replacing human brilliance. Itâ€™s replacing tasks . And thatâ€™s not the same thing. Look at the studies: a Stanford + MIT analysis found that access to generative AI improved productivity for customer support agents by 14% , with the largest gains for novice workers. Thatâ€™s not replacement â€” itâ€™s augmentation. The question leaders should be asking isnâ€™t â€œHow do we replace people with AI?â€ Itâ€™s â€œWhat work has been constrained by capacity, budget, or bandwidth that AI can help unlock â€” so our people can focus on the complex, creative, human work?â€ Because hereâ€™s the truth: if youâ€™re calling your company a â€œfamilyâ€ while cutting loyal staff the second AI looks cheaper, donâ€™t expect trust, or talent, to stick around. The Generational Factor Millennials and Gen Z arenâ€™t buying into the old bargain: grind until retirement, maybe enjoy one vacation, then die. Surveys show that Gen Z is already rejecting leadership roles in some organizations because the trade-off â€” burnout, liability, endless stress â€” doesnâ€™t feel worth it. Millennials, raised at the hinge of analog and digital, are leading differently: less micromanagement, more autonomy, flattened hierarchies. Gen Z, often criticized as â€œlazyâ€ or â€œself-centered,â€ brings something executives desperately need: emotional intelligence, cultural awareness, and a sharp read on what feels morally or socially relevant right now. Press enter or click to view image in full size A new generation of workers focusing on cultural health â€” building workplaces centered on trust, flexibility, and human connection. Every generation has something to offer. But if leaders ignore the priorities of Millennials and Gen Z, flexibility, wellness, authenticity, theyâ€™ll find themselves with empty pipelines and rising turnover. A Framework for Future-Ready Culture Hereâ€™s what I tell leaders who ask me how to prepare: Start with vision. Whatâ€™s your actual strategic vision by 2030? What problem are you solving? Without clarity, no AI tool or hybrid policy will save you. Do a cultural diagnostic. Donâ€™t just measure KPIs. Assess your systems, practices, people, and cultural health. Where are people silenced? Where are they disengaged? Where is the architecture weak? Redesign for flexibility. That doesnâ€™t mean â€œgo fully remote.â€ It means create breathable systems, where different teams can work in ways that optimize for output, well-being, and reality. Integrate AI responsibly. Build governance. Train your people. Make AI a teammate, not a replacement. And never outsource creativity or moral judgment. Communicate like your survival depends on it. Because it does. Silence and fear cost more than mistakes. Psychological safety is a business imperative. The Future of Work is Human AI is extraordinary. It will reshape industries. But if we forget the human system underneath â€” if we treat culture like wallpaper instead of architecture â€” we will implode. The organizations that thrive wonâ€™t be the ones with the flashiest AI adoption. Theyâ€™ll be the ones who build trust, flexibility, and cultural health into their DNA. Because the future of work isnâ€™t about tech. Itâ€™s about us. If youâ€™re leading through this shift, ask yourself: is your culture strong enough to hold the weight of AI? Follow me on LinkedIn for practical insights, and on Substack for deeper essays. Donâ€™t just watch history â€” help write it. Fear Is Not Free â€” Itâ€™s Bankrupting Your Workplace Why fear-led management destroys culture, drains performance, and costs companies their best people. Samantha Truman Sep 24, 2025 Share A lot of people misunderstand workplace abuse and emotional manipulation as motivation. Read that again. Iâ€™ve seen leaders who believe fear is fuel. Who confuse control for culture. Who think metrics are the only map they need. And yes, those leaders can get short-term results. But long-term? Itâ€™s a house of cards. Photo by Ryan Moulton on Unsplash The End of Fear-Led Systems People today are done with fear-led leadership. You see it in the streets as much as in boardroomsâ€”marches for light, meaning, justice, and joy. Why would anyone clock in every day for environments that feel darker? That old model â€” Gordon Gekko swagger, Wolf of Wall Street bravado â€” thrived on fear and audacity. But future generations wonâ€™t tolerate it. Millennials and Gen Z are accountability-centric. Theyâ€™ll leave. Theyâ€™ll walk. Theyâ€™ll build or find systems that actually value them. Fear Drains Performance Fear-based management doesnâ€™t just hurt feelings; it wrecks performance. ðŸ“Š APA (2023): 77% of employees experience work-related stress, and nearly 60% report negative impacts on mental health. Burnout is not a buzzword. Itâ€™s a business liability. Burnout is not a buzzword. Itâ€™s a business liability. Radical Transparency Hereâ€™s my proposal: tell the truth up front. If your company is going to treat people like expendable parts, say it. If you know people will leave in two years because your infrastructure is rigid, say it. If you donâ€™t intend to prioritize employee growth, say it. At least then, people can decide with eyes open. They can prepare themselves. They wonâ€™t walk away saying, â€œDang it, they almost got me again.â€ That level of honesty could reset the relationship between work and workers. Building Cultures That Last Because hereâ€™s the reality: Passion is fuel. Integrity is alignment. Care is strategy. You can hit profits and KPIs without cruelty. You can drive performance without breaking people. ðŸ“Š Deloitte Human Capital Trends (2023): Organizations prioritizing human sustainability are 2.2x more likely to outperform financially. When leadership is grounded in something deeper than fear, you stop mistaking manipulation for motivationâ€”and start building cultures that actually last. fear-led management destroys culture, drains performance, and costs companies their best people.\",\"body_html\":\" A lot of people misunderstand workplace abuse and emotional manipulation as motivation. Read that again. I\u2019ve seen leaders who believe fear is fuel. Who confuse control for culture. Who think metrics are the only map they need. And yes, those leaders can get short-term results. But long-term? It\u2019s a house of cards. Photo by Ryan Moulton on Unsplash The End of Fear-Led Systems People today are done with fear-led leadership. You see it in the streets as much as in boardrooms\u2014marches for light, meaning, justice, and joy. Why would anyone clock in every day for environments that feel darker? That old model \u2014 Gordon Gekko swagger, Wolf of Wall Street bravado \u2014 thrived on fear and audacity. But future generations won\u2019t tolerate it. Millennials and Gen Z are accountability-centric. They\u2019ll leave. They\u2019ll walk. They\u2019ll build or find systems that actually value them. Fear Drains Performance Fear-based management doesn\u2019t just hurt feelings; it wrecks performance. \uD83D\uDCCA APA (2023): 77% of employees experience work-related stress, and nearly 60% report negative impacts on mental health. Burnout is not a buzzword. It\u2019s a business liability. Photo by Larry Nalzaro on Unsplash Fear Drains Performance Fear-based management doesn\u2019t just hurt feelings; it wrecks performance. \uD83D\uDCCA APA (2023): 77% of employees experience work-related stress, and nearly 60% report negative impacts on mental health. Burnout is not a buzzword. It\u2019s a business liability. Radical Transparency Here\u2019s my proposal: tell the truth up front. If your company is going to treat people like expendable parts, say it. If you know people will leave in two years because your infrastructure is rigid, say it. If you don\u2019t intend to prioritize employee growth, say it. At least then, people can decide with eyes open. They can prepare themselves. They won\u2019t walk away saying, \u201CDang it, they almost got me again.\u201D That level of honesty could reset the relationship between work and workers. Building Cultures That Last Because here\u2019s the reality: Passion is fuel. Integrity is alignment. Care is strategy. You can hit profits and KPIs without cruelty. You can drive performance without breaking people. \uD83D\uDCCA Deloitte Human Capital Trends (2023): Organizations prioritizing human sustainability are 2.2x more likely to outperform financially. When leadership is grounded in something deeper than fear, you stop mistaking manipulation for motivation\u2014and start building cultures that actually last. If this hit home, it might be time to assess your own culture. Check out True People Consulting\u2019s CultureShift Diagnostic\u2122 \u2014a framework designed to surface hidden costs of fear and chart a better way forward. \",\"truncated_body_text\":\"A lot of people misunderstand workplace abuse and emotional manipulation as motivation. Share What burnout taught me about the system thatâ€™s making us sick. W hen I finally made it to the top, I didnâ€™t feel proud. I felt sick. I remember looking in the mirror â€” 190 pounds, heart failing, the spark gone from my eyes. The paychecks were good. The travel, the clothes, the cars, the house â€” all there. But the light was gone. And that was the moment I realized: the problem wasnâ€™t money. It was the system. The infrastructure. The way things are built in our workplaces and in our societies. Because when I looked around, I saw sickness everywhere. People smiling while silently dying inside. Burnout. Isolation. Absurd health conditions. Shortened lives. People working themselves into the ground and still struggling to afford a decent meal. You canâ€™t convince me this is what God had in mind for us. You canâ€™t tell me a loving God designed a world where joy is a luxury and exhaustion is proof of worth. Thatâ€™s when it hit me â€” the system isnâ€™t broken. Itâ€™s working. It was built to function this way: extractive, performative, and indifferent to the human condition. Press enter or click to view image in full size The windmills in Pirogovo, Ukraine â€” where the sky is impossibly blue and endlessly wide, a reminder of what still matters when everything else falls away. And itâ€™s not just one industry. Iâ€™ve worked across them all â€” healthcare, tech, education, corporate. Iâ€™ve facilitated to over twenty thousand people, advised executive leaders, sat in rooms where everyone talked about innovation but no one talked about humanity. No matter where I went, the sickness followed. Different offices, same symptoms. Because people are people â€” and when systems are sick, people suffer. Iâ€™ve mastered the hustle. Iâ€™ve studied it from every angle â€” as the employee, the consultant, the executive, the founder. And the hardest life lesson Iâ€™ve learned is this: if you donâ€™t know where youâ€™re going, youâ€™ll end up lost â€” sometimes in a corner of your own making. I got lost inside achievement. I got lost inside perfection. I got lost inside systems that rewarded my silence and called it professionalism. And when I finally saw how unrecognizable Iâ€™d become, I had to ask myself: how did the system transform me? How did I let it dim my light, drain my spirit, erase my essence â€” and for what? A paycheck? A car? A title? It wasnâ€™t worth it. Because no matter how far I climbed, I couldnâ€™t escape the truth: weâ€™re building lives inside infrastructures that were never built for our well-being. And I refuse to perform wellness for systems that make people sick. I want to build happy people and happy systems. Thatâ€™s what my work whispers beneath it all. Thatâ€™s the call. Because if you want to see better, you have to be willing to look at the rot. And most people donâ€™t want to go there. But thatâ€™s where the real work begins. The System That Made Me Sick: How Work Lost Its Humanity It didnâ€™t matter where I went â€” tech, healthcare, corporate, nonprofits â€” the same sickness followed. Different names, same disease. Iâ€™ve been in so many organizations, dissected them from the inside, and no matter how fancy the strategy deck, the truth is always the same: people are people, and most systems are sick. I first realized it when I looked around and noticed how much pain weâ€™ve normalized. This when I realized that we are entering the 2030 Renaissance . Suicide rates high. Burnout everywhere. You canâ€™t even walk into a supermarket and buy a healthy meal half the time because people are living paycheck to paycheck. Press enter or click to view image in full size Portland, Jamaica â€” the place that taught me the system was never just corporate. It was cultural. Generational. Colonial. And it still shapes how we work today. The system works exactly as it was built to â€” extractive, performative, and indifferent to the soul. Itâ€™s not broken. It was designed this way. And Iâ€™ve been in enough rooms to know: most people arenâ€™t ready to face that truth. Because if they did, theyâ€™d have to change something. When I first entered the culture industry and specialized in DEI, I thought Iâ€™d finally found my people. Finally, we were talking about harm, about invisibility, about the weight that underrepresented people carry. I thought, yes, this is the work. But then I started to see the same patterns repeating â€” the same corporate performance, the same fear of real accountability, the same obsession with language and optics while people on the ground were still breaking. You canâ€™t decorate decay. You have to name it. You have to face it. And when you do, you realize most of our workplaces are just mirrors of society: beautiful from afar, corroded underneath. Iâ€™ve sat with executives who talk about â€œtransformationâ€ but refuse to give up control. Iâ€™ve seen people say they want change, but not costly change. Iâ€™ve watched good people silence themselves because speaking the truth might cost them their position, their reputation, or their peace. So no, the problem isnâ€™t just cultural â€” itâ€™s spiritual. And thatâ€™s why I do what I do. The Survival: Living Through the Workplace Burnout Epidemic Before I built systems, I survived them. I was born in Ukraine to a Ukrainian mother and a Jamaican father. Then moved to Jamaica with a professional tyrant for a father â€” cunning, volatile, and cruel. My childhood was a masterclass in adaptation. I learned early that survival meant reading the room, staying quiet, moving strategically. Eventually, I made it to California at fourteen with my mother and Palestinian stepfather â€” silenced, shape-shifting to fit the world around me. I buried my accent for safety. Wore the same clothes week after week. Tried to pass. Tried to belong. Tried to disappear just enough to survive. I had grit. That was never the problem. Itâ€™s what kept me alive. By sixteen, I shaved my head. I needed a purge. By seventeen, I was homeless. And still, I fought. Because even then, I could imagine a future better than the one I was living I became a filmmaker. Then a shopping host on cruise ships. A flight attendant. A consultant. A corporate leader. Now, a founder. Iâ€™ve lived in every layer of the hierarchy â€” from paycheck-to-paycheck employee to executive insider. And what I learned at every level is this: the sickness doesnâ€™t discriminate. It just changes clothes. Press enter or click to view image in full size Samantha Truman, producing her first feature film at 18. Before the deadlines, the deliverables, the exhaustion â€” before the spark began to slip away. Iâ€™ve seen it in blue-collar workers afraid to call in sick. In executives terrified to be seen as human. In young people confusing busyness with purpose. In elders counting down to retirement like itâ€™s salvation. Iâ€™ve lived it too â€” the performing, the over-giving, the disappearing. The slow erasure of self in systems that call it ambition. And then one day, my body rebelled. Heart failure. Ten years of undiagnosed hypertension. My body had been whispering for years, but I was too busy proving myself to listen. When it finally screamed, I had to. Thatâ€™s when I realized: the system isnâ€™t only outside of us â€” itâ€™s inside of us. Itâ€™s the voices that say â€œwork harder.â€ Itâ€™s the fear that if you slow down, youâ€™ll lose your worth. Itâ€™s the conditioning that tells you to hide the parts that donâ€™t look like power. So I stopped. I stopped performing survival. I stopped making myself smaller for systems that couldnâ€™t hold me. I stopped calling sickness â€œsuccess.â€ And I made a decision: if the world was going to keep building systems that break people, Iâ€™d spend the rest of my life building systems that breathe. Because Iâ€™ve lived what happens when we donâ€™t. Iâ€™ve been the girl who had nothing. The woman who had everything. And the human who realized that both are empty if youâ€™ve lost your soul in the process. The Surrender: Redefining Success, Rest, and Human-Centered Leadership At some point, the fight has to stop. Not because youâ€™ve lost â€” but because youâ€™ve finally realized you donâ€™t have to fight yourself to live. In 2025, I walked away from an executive role to focus on building for the future. Not someone elseâ€™s future â€” mine. Humanityâ€™s. For the first time, I stopped running long enough to look in the mirror and really see. I did an exercise I now call â€œthe good, the bad, and the ugly.â€ The â€œuglyâ€ section was so long it scared me. It was a mirror I couldnâ€™t look away from. Every mistake, every betrayal, every way Iâ€™d silenced myself, every version of me that had learned to perform strength because no one ever taught her safety. And instead of editing it, I faced it. That version of me â€” the one who could finally look at everything â€” surrendered. Not to defeat, but to truth. Because sometimes the ugliest parts of you are the ones that most need your compassion. You donâ€™t heal by hiding what happened. You heal by accepting it, naming it, and releasing the shame attached to it. Press enter or click to view image in full size Lisbon, Portugal â€” Samantha Truman with her then-toddler. Another beautiful escape that couldnâ€™t fix what she refused to face. Thatâ€™s what surrender was for me â€” the choice to stop running from myself. It didnâ€™t mean smiling through it. It meant standing in the middle of it and saying, yes, this happened. And itâ€™s not all of who I am. Because when the spark leaves your eyes, you have to fight to get it back. And the first fight isnâ€™t with the world â€” itâ€™s with yourself. You have to ask: how did I let the system make me unrecognizable? How did I let my circumstances corner my spirit? How did I trade the dreams that once kept me alive for metrics that mean nothing? I had to face the truth: I had built a beautiful life around my exhaustion. I had made success out of survival. So, I stopped calling it ambition when it was really avoidance. I stopped calling it resilience when it was really repression. And I stopped calling it leadership when it was really loss. Surrender is what made room for peace. Peace didnâ€™t come when I achieved more. It came when I decided I didnâ€™t have to earn my right to rest. Thatâ€™s when I began to rebuild â€” not the version of me the system wanted, but the one who could finally breathe. The Spark Returns: Rebuilding a Future-Ready Culture That Breathes When I stopped lying to myself, the light began to return. Slowly, at first â€” like morning through fog. It started with small things: breathing deeper, sitting still, watching the mountain outside my home catch fire at sunset. Thereâ€™s a moment each evening when the light hits the ridge, and doves fly across the sky. Every time I see them, I think, thereâ€™s still hope. Because there is. Press enter or click to view image in full size The sunset that makes life worth living â€” proof that light always returns, even after you forget what warmth feels like. I believe we can build systems that make people well. I believe culture can be infrastructure, not performance. I believe organizations can be designed like living organisms â€” breathing, adapting, healing. Thatâ€™s what my work is now: to build happy people and happy systems, to make sure the light never leaves anyoneâ€™s eyes again. â€œLove is patient, love is kindâ€¦â€ â€” but our systems are neither. They rush and consume. They measure everything except meaning. I donâ€™t want to just reform work; I want to reimagine it. To teach leaders how to hold truth without collapsing. To show teams how to turn conflict into clarity. To help people remember that their humanity was never the problem. Because when we say â€œfuture of work,â€ we canâ€™t just mean tech and AI and new tools. We have to mean us. How we treat each other. How we tell the truth. How we repair whatâ€™s been broken. The future of work is spiritual work. And Iâ€™m not afraid to say it anymore. The Revolution: Why the Future of Work Is Spiritual Work We are in a global emotional crisis. People are exhausted, disconnected, surviving more than theyâ€™re living. We call it burnout, but itâ€™s really grief â€” grief for the selves we lost while trying to belong. Weâ€™ve built a world that rewards silence, obedience, and performance, and then we wonder why no one feels alive. But Iâ€™ve seen the other side. Iâ€™ve seen what happens when people tell the truth. When leaders choose accountability over image. When organizations make space for the full complexity of being human. Something shifts. The air changes. People start breathing again. Thatâ€™s the revolution I believe in â€” the quiet kind. The kind that starts in meeting rooms, classrooms, kitchens, and mirrors. The kind that starts when one person decides not to pretend anymore. We donâ€™t need another campaign or corporate slogan. We need a spiritual wake-up call. We need courage, compassion, and new architecture. We need to stop calling the sickness normal. I know what it feels like to lose yourself in the name of success. And I know what it feels like to find yourself again. The spark that left my eyes â€” it came back. And now my work is to help others find theirs. Press enter or click to view image in full size Samantha Truman in the mountains â€” where the air is clear and the work is spiritual. Because the real revolution is remembering what it means to feel alive. History will remember the builders of systems that breathe â€” the ones who chose repair over performance, the ones who remembered that work was always meant to serve life, not replace it. The spark came back. The question is â€” will you let yours return?
