For the first time, I stopped running long enough to look in the mirror and really see.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_29":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_29","name":"6a06","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I did an exercise I now call â€œthe good, the bad, and the ugly.â€ The â€œuglyâ€ section was so long it scared me. It was a mirror I couldnâ€™t look away from. Every mistake, every betrayal, every way Iâ€™d silenced myself, every version of me that had learned to perform strength because no one ever taught her safety.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_30":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_30","name":"06c0","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"And instead of editing it, I faced it. That version of me â€” the one who could finally look at everything â€” surrendered. Not to defeat, but to truth. Because sometimes the ugliest parts of you are the ones that most need your compassion. You donâ€™t heal by hiding what happened. You heal by accepting it, naming it, and releasing the shame attached to it.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:1*g-1eby4bv1OEsBNF-wpIMA.jpeg":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"1*g-1eby4bv1OEsBNF-wpIMA.jpeg","originalHeight":3024,"originalWidth":4032,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_31":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_31","name":"08b4","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:1*g-1eby4bv1OEsBNF-wpIMA.jpeg"},"text":"Lisbon, Portugal â€” Samantha Truman with her then-toddler. Another beautiful escape that couldnâ€™t fix what she refused to face.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_32":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_32","name":"0115","type":"BQ","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Thatâ€™s what surrender was for me â€” the choice to stop running from myself. It didnâ€™t mean smiling through it. It meant standing in the middle of it and saying, yes, this happened. And itâ€™s not all of who I am. Because when the spark leaves your eyes, you have to fight to get it back. And the first fight isnâ€™t with the world â€” itâ€™s with yourself.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_33":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_33","name":"3adc","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"You have to ask: how did I let the system make me unrecognizable? How did I let my circumstances corner my spirit? How did I trade the dreams that once kept me alive for metrics that mean nothing? I had to face the truth: I had built a beautiful life around my exhaustion. I had made success out of survival. So, I stopped calling it ambition when it was really avoidance. I stopped calling it resilience when it was really repression. And I stopped calling it leadership when it was really loss.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_34":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_34","name":"5f7d","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Surrender is what made room for peace. Peace didnâ€™t come when I achieved more. It came when I decided I didnâ€™t have to earn my right to rest. Thatâ€™s when I began to rebuild â€” not the version of me the system wanted, but the one who could finally breathe.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_35":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_35","name":"1eff","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Spark Returns: Rebuilding a Future-Ready Culture That Breathes","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_36":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_36","name":"4f71","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"When I stopped lying to myself, the light began to return. Slowly, at first â€” like morning through fog. It started with small things: breathing deeper, sitting still, watching the mountain outside my home catch fire at sunset. Thereâ€™s a moment each evening when the light hits the ridge, and doves fly across the sky. Every time I see them, I think, thereâ€™s still hope. Because there is.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":350,"end":369,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:1*yeqe82ZlSRGtNsdan9EzkA.jpeg":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"1*yeqe82ZlSRGtNsdan9EzkA.jpeg","originalHeight":1611,"originalWidth":3024,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_37":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_37","name":"2da9","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:1*yeqe82ZlSRGtNsdan9EzkA.jpeg"},"text":"The sunset that makes life worth living â€” proof that light always returns, even after you forget what warmth feels like.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_38":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_38","name":"30dd","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I believe we can build systems that make people well. I believe culture can be infrastructure, not performance. I believe organizations can be designed like living organisms â€” breathing, adapting, healing. Thatâ€™s what my work is now: to build happy people and happy systems, to make sure the light never leaves anyoneâ€™s eyes again.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_39":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_39","name":"eb08","type":"BQ","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"â€œLove is patient, love is kindâ€¦â€ â€” but our systems are neither. They rush and consume. They measure everything except meaning. I donâ€™t want to just reform work; I want to reimagine it. To teach leaders how to hold truth without collapsing. To show teams how to turn conflict into clarity. To help people remember that their humanity was never the problem.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_40":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_40","name":"1db2","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Because when we say â€œfuture of work,â€ we canâ€™t just mean tech and AI and new tools. We have to mean us. How we treat each other. How we tell the truth. How we repair whatâ€™s been broken. The future of work is spiritual work. And Iâ€™m not afraid to say it anymore.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":100,"end":103,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_41":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_41","name":"a3bd","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Revolution: Why the Future of Work Is Spiritual Work","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_42":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_42","name":"5f73","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"We are in a global emotional crisis. People are exhausted, disconnected, surviving more than theyâ€™re living. We call it burnout, but itâ€™s really grief â€” grief for the selves we lost while trying to belong. Weâ€™ve built a world that rewards silence, obedience, and performance, and then we wonder why no one feels alive.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_43":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_43","name":"0625","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"But Iâ€™ve seen the other side. Iâ€™ve seen what happens when people tell the truth. When leaders choose accountability over image. When organizations make space for the full complexity of being human. Something shifts. The air changes. People start breathing again.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_44":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_44","name":"5b4f","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Thatâ€™s the revolution I believe in â€” the quiet kind. The kind that starts in meeting rooms, classrooms, kitchens, and mirrors. The kind that starts when one person decides not to pretend anymore. We donâ€™t need another campaign or corporate slogan. We need a spiritual wake-up call. We need courage, compassion, and new architecture. We need to stop calling the sickness normal.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_45":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_45","name":"b52e","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"I know what it feels like to lose yourself in the name of success. And I know what it feels like to find yourself again. The spark that left my eyes â€” it came back. And now my work is to help others find theirs.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"ImageMetadata:1*-xk4-ueftpu1nOJqWCmZog.jpeg":{"__typename":"ImageMetadata","id":"1*-xk4-ueftpu1nOJqWCmZog.jpeg","originalHeight":4032,"originalWidth":3024,"focusPercentX":null,"focusPercentY":null,"alt":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_46":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_46","name":"1367","type":"IMG","href":null,"layout":"INSET_CENTER","metadata":{"__ref":"ImageMetadata:1*-xk4-ueftpu1nOJqWCmZog.jpeg"},"text":"Samantha Truman in the mountains â€” where the air is clear and the work is spiritual. Because the real revolution is remembering what it means to feel alive.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_47":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_47","name":"1737","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"History will remember the builders of systems that breathe â€” the ones who chose repair over performance, the ones who remembered that work was always meant to serve life, not replace it. The spark came back. The question is â€” will you let yours return?","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":208,"end":252,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_48":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_48","name":"f7f9","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Samantha Truman is the Founder of True People Consulting, a culture and strategy firm helping organizations design the future of work â€” not as a performance, but as a living system. Sheâ€™s known for her frameworks on cultural health, psychological safety, and future-ready leadership, and her voice at the intersection of equity, spirituality, and systems design.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"A","start":34,"end":56,"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftruepeopleconsulting.com\u002F","anchorType":"LINK","userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":34,"end":56,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":0,"end":362,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_49":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_49","name":"5120","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Her mission is simple: to build happy people and happy systems. If this resonated, share it â€” or reach out. Because culture doesnâ€™t change through slogans. It changes through us.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":0,"end":178,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:6d7c7aeaadfa_50":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"6d7c7aeaadfa_50","name":"1050","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Follow Samantha on LinkedIn or join her community on Substack for more essays on the emotional economy and the future of leadership.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"A","start":19,"end":27,"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.linkedin.com\u002Fin\u002Fsamanthatruman\u002F","anchorType":"LINK","userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"A","start":53,"end":61,"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.linkedin.com\u002Fin\u002Fsamanthatruman\u002F","anchorType":"LINK","userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":19,"end":27,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":53,"end":61,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":0,"end":132,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"UserViewerEdge:userId:bb0c8c527d6b-viewerId:lo_cb046d8ad2f4":{"__typename":"UserViewerEdge","id":"userId:bb0c8c527d6b-viewerId:lo_cb046d8ad2f4","isMuting":false},"PostViewerEdge:postId:eba8aa66a460-viewerId:lo_cb046d8ad2f4":{"__typename":"PostViewerEdge","shouldIndexPostForExternalSearch":true,"id":"postId:eba8aa66a460-viewerId:lo_cb046d8ad2f4"},"Tag:burnout":{"__typename":"Tag","id":"burnout","displayTitle":"Burnout","normalizedTagSlug":"burnout"},"Tag:health":{"__typename":"Tag","id":"health","displayTitle":"Health","normalizedTagSlug":"health"},"Tag:success":{"__typename":"Tag","id":"success","displayTitle":"Success","normalizedTagSlug":"success"},"Tag:leadership":{"__typename":"Tag","id":"leadership","displayTitle":"Leadership","normalizedTagSlug":"leadership"},"Tag:business":{"__typename":"Tag","id":"business","displayTitle":"Business","normalizedTagSlug":"business"},"Post:eba8aa66a460":{"__typename":"Post","id":"eba8aa66a460","collection":null,"content({\"postMeteringOptions\":{\"referrer\":\"\"}})":{"__typename":"PostContent","isLockedPreviewOnly":false,"bodyModel":{"__typename":"RichText","sections":[{"__t Why Leaders Miss the $8.8 Trillion Problem Hiding in Their Culture Workplace culture failures cost $8.8T globally. Leaders miss it because they focus on metrics, not the invisible architecture of work. Samantha Truman Sep 19, 2025 1 Share The Invisible Architecture of Work: Seeing What Leaders Miss When we talk about culture, most people think about surface-level things: team lunches, a values poster, the annual retreat. But culture isnâ€™t whatâ€™s written on the wall. Itâ€™s the invisible architecture underneathâ€”the unspoken agreements, the quiet fears, the subtle signals that shape how people actually move through the system. And hereâ€™s the hard truth: leaders often miss it. Thanks for reading The Culture Room! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Subscribe Theyâ€™re looking at dashboards. Theyâ€™re looking at strategy decks. Theyâ€™re listening to a few loud voices in the room. But theyâ€™re not paying attention to what lives beneathâ€”the human system where work and real life collide. Iâ€™ve seen it over and over: the immigrant employee navigating systemic bias at work with the same exhaustion she carries outside; the new manager who feels like a survivalist rather than a leader because the â€œempowermentâ€ promised on paper isnâ€™t matched by trust in practice; the high-potential Black woman who never speaks in executive meetingsâ€”not because she lacks confidence, but because sheâ€™s calculated that the risk outweighs the reward. This is what I call the invisible architecture. Itâ€™s the weight of inequity, power, and unspoken rules that employees carry into every interaction. Itâ€™s not about perks. Itâ€™s about survival. The Economic Cost of Ignoring Culture And the cost of ignoring this system is massive. Gallup found that only 32% of U.S. employees are engaged, while 51% are â€œnot engagedâ€ and 13% are â€œactively disengaged.â€ That means two-thirds of your workforce is essentially checked out . The economic cost? $8.8 trillion globallyâ€”about 9% of world GDP . Thatâ€™s not just a people issue. Thatâ€™s your bottom line bleeding. When leaders ask me why their strategy isnâ€™t sticking, or why turnover is spiking, or why performance feels flat despite strong hiring, the answer usually isnâ€™t in the strategy at all. Itâ€™s in the invisible architecture. Share The Culture Room Questions Leaders Arenâ€™t Asking The problem is, you canâ€™t see it if youâ€™re only looking at quarterly reports or sanitized employee surveys. You have to get underneath. You have to ask the harder questions: What are the unspoken rules in this system? Where do people feel silenced, unsafe, or unseen? What cultural â€œtaxesâ€ are women, people of color, caregivers, or immigrants paying just to survive the day? How do our systems unintentionally reward silence and punish truth? Leaders who canâ€™tâ€”or wonâ€™tâ€”see this architecture will always misdiagnose their problems. Theyâ€™ll double down on perks, restructure, swap executives, or launch new initiatives, while the root cause goes untouched. What Brave Leaders See But leaders who do see itâ€”who are willing to face the invisible architectureâ€”unlock something rare. They build cultures that breathe. Cultures where people donâ€™t just endure the system, they shape it. Thatâ€™s the real work of cultural strategy. Not slogans. Not â€œresilience workshops.â€ But reshaping the architecture itself so people donâ€™t have to contort themselves just to belong. Because culture isnâ€™t just about what happens at work. Itâ€™s about whether people can bring their full humanity to the tableâ€”and whether leaders are brave enough to see what theyâ€™ve been missing. If youâ€™re a leader whoâ€™s ready to look beyond dashboards and face the invisible architecture of your culture, subscribe for more essaysâ€”or connect with me on LinkedIn . The cost of silence is too high to ignore. Message Samantha Truman Thanks for reading The Culture Room! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Leaders miss it because they focus on metrics, not the invisible architecture of work.\",\"teaser_post_eligible\":true,\"title\":\"Why Leaders Miss the $8.8 Trillion Problem Hiding in Their Culture\",\"type\":\"newsletter\",\"video_upload_id\":null,\"write_comment_permissions\":\"everyone\",\"meter_type\":\"none\",\"live_stream_id\":null,\"is_published\":true,\"restacks\":0,\"reactions\":{\"\u2764\":1},\"top_exclusions\":[],\"pins\":[],\"section_pins\":[],\"has_shareable_clips\":false,\"previous_post_slug\":\"the-5-pillars-of-cultural-health\",\"next_post_slug\":\"the-romance-lie-how-culture-protects\",\"cover_image\":\"https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!uBfk!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F5f01ab47-4bea-4067-80db-ebcfcb749df1_5376x3520.jpeg\",\"cover_image_is_square\":false,\"cover_image_is_explicit\":false,\"videoUpload\":null,\"podcastFields\":{\"post_id\":173950708,\"podcast_episode_number\":null,\"podcast_season_number\":null,\"podcast_episode_type\":null,\"should_syndicate_to_other_feed\":null,\"syndicate_to_section_id\":null,\"hide_from_feed\":false,\"free_podcast_url\":null,\"free_podcast_duration\":null},\"podcastUpload\":null,\"podcastPreviewUpload\":null,\"voiceover_upload_id\":null,\"voiceoverUpload\":null,\"has_voiceover\":false,\"description\":\"Workplace culture failures cost $8.8T globally. Leaders miss it because they focus on metrics, not the invisible architecture of work.\",\"body_html\":\" The Invisible Architecture of Work: Seeing What Leaders Miss When we talk about culture, most people think about surface-level things: team lunches, a values poster, the annual retreat. But culture isn\u2019t what\u2019s written on the wall. It\u2019s the invisible architecture underneath\u2014the unspoken agreements, the quiet fears, the subtle signals that shape how people actually move through the system. And here\u2019s the hard truth: leaders often miss it. Thanks for reading The Culture Room! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. They\u2019re looking at dashboards. They\u2019re looking at strategy decks. They\u2019re listening to a few loud voices in the room. But they\u2019re not paying attention to what lives beneath\u2014the human system where work and real life collide. I\u2019ve seen it over and over: the immigrant employee navigating systemic bias at work with the same exhaustion she carries outside; the new manager who feels like a survivalist rather than a leader because the \u201Cempowerment\u201D promised on paper isn\u2019t matched by trust in practice; the high-potential Black woman who never speaks in executive meetings\u2014not because she lacks confidence, but because she\u2019s calculated that the risk outweighs the reward. This is what I call the invisible architecture. It\u2019s the weight of inequity, power, and unspoken rules that employees carry into every interaction. It\u2019s not about perks. It\u2019s about survival. The Economic Cost of Ignoring Culture And the cost of ignoring this system is massive. Gallup found that only 32% of U.S. employees are engaged, while 51% are \u201Cnot engaged\u201D and 13% are \u201Cactively disengaged.\u201D That means two-thirds of your workforce is essentially checked out . The economic cost? $8.8 trillion globally\u2014about 9% of world GDP . That\u2019s not just a people issue. That\u2019s your bottom line bleeding. When leaders ask me why their strategy isn\u2019t sticking, or why turnover is spiking, or why performance feels flat despite strong hiring, the answer usually isn\u2019t in the strategy at all. It\u2019s in the invisible architecture. Share The Culture Room Questions Leaders Aren\u2019t Asking The problem is, you can\u2019t see it if you\u2019re only looking at quarterly reports or sanitized employee surveys. You have to get underneath. You have to ask the harder questions: What are the unspoken rules in this system? Where do people feel silenced, unsafe, or unseen? What cultural \u201Ctaxes\u201D are women, people of color, caregivers, or immigrants paying just to survive the day? How do our systems unintentionally reward silence and punish truth? Leaders who can\u2019t\u2014or won\u2019t\u2014see this architecture will always misdiagnose their problems. They\u2019ll double down on perks, restructure, swap executives, or launch new initiatives, while the root cause goes untouched. What Brave Leaders See But leaders who do see it\u2014who are willing to face the invisible architecture\u2014unlock something rare. They build cultures that breathe. Cultures where people don\u2019t just endure the system, they shape it. That\u2019s the real work of cultural strategy. Not slogans. Not \u201Cresilience workshops.\u201D But reshaping the architecture itself so people don\u2019t have to contort themselves just to belong. Because culture isn\u2019t just about what happens at work. It\u2019s about whether people can bring their full humanity to the table\u2014and whether leaders are brave enough to see what they\u2019ve been missing. If you\u2019re a leader who\u2019s ready to look beyond dashboards and face the invisible architecture of your culture, subscribe for more essays\u2014or connect with me on LinkedIn . The cost of silence is too high to ignore. Thanks for reading The Culture Room! Performance) Samantha Truman 5 min read Â· 6 days ago -- Listen Share W hen I first read about the Deloitte report scandal, I wasnâ€™t shocked. I remembered a conversation from a job interview I had with Deloitte a few years ago. I asked the recruiter about their structure, and she told me that consultantsâ€™ laptop activity was monitored. She also mentioned, almost casually, that it wasnâ€™t unusual for consultants to work sixty hours a week. I donâ€™t balk at hard work; but I require integrity in what I invest my time toward. The cultural cues in that conversation were loud: control, surveillance, relentless output. I declined to move forward on the call. Based on that conversation and the cultural cues I picked up, I realized their lifestyle wasnâ€™t for me. The pace wasnâ€™t the problem; the posture was. Press enter or click to view image in full size Now, seeing that Deloitte delivered a AUD $440,000 report to an Australian government agency riddled with AI hallucinations and fabricated citations, I am not surprised. That kind of foundational crack is rarely sudden. It reflects a culture that deprioritized care, accountability, and rigorous truth in favor of velocity and performance. The Guardian reported that Deloitte agreed to refund part of the fee after discovering that sections of the report included invented references. ABC News confirmed that Deloitte partially refunded the payment after the Department of Industry and Science raised concerns about accuracy. The Australian Financial Review later published Deloitteâ€™s apology, quoting the firmâ€™s statement that â€œoversight was not followed.â€ Even after the revision, journalists found more errors and â€œirrelevant citations.â€ Thatâ€™s not a technical glitch â€” thatâ€™s a cultural failure. When Culture Becomes the Weakest Link When a companyâ€™s focus is anchored solely on ROI and KPI, culture quietly slips through the cracks. You see it everywhere: metrics without meaning, speed without scrutiny, and work that is measured in volume instead of value. In Deloitteâ€™s case, the report was meant to inform public strategy â€” to help a government make decisions for its people. And yet, somehow, an internal culture that prized speed and volume over integrity allowed shortcuts to pass as substance. When leaders create a culture that glorifies output at all costs, truth becomes negotiable. If you donâ€™t take pride in the work that informs policy and public trust, what do you take pride in? Itâ€™s possible this failure wasnâ€™t systemic across Deloitte. It could have been one team, one region, one oversight. But the question worth asking is: Why did this happen even once? What systems of accountability allowed it to? And more importantly, what kind of cultural environment makes professionals so rushed, so pressured, or so desensitized that integrity slips by unnoticed? Psychological Safety Isnâ€™t Just a Buzzword In theory, consulting firms talk about â€œpsychological safety.â€ In practice, itâ€™s often the first casualty of a deadline. When people feel they canâ€™t question authority or push back against unrealistic timelines, thatâ€™s not psychological safety ; thatâ€™s quiet compliance. Letâ€™s imagine a hypothetical moment: A junior analyst raises a concern, â€œI canâ€™t find a source for this citation. Should we leave it out?â€ A manager replies, â€œJust keep it moving. Weâ€™re already late.â€ That moment, the instant when someone chooses convenience over correctness , is where culture reveals itself. Itâ€™s not malice. Itâ€™s momentum. And when momentum outruns integrity, failure becomes inevitable. When Values Become Performance Iâ€™ve watched consulting firms betray the very values they sell. Many of them are sincere people trapped in systems optimized for optics. â€œIntegrityâ€ becomes a brand attribute, not a behavior. â€œAccountabilityâ€ becomes a slide deck, not a standard. Iâ€™ve met leaders who couldnâ€™t recite their companyâ€™s mission but could tell you last quarterâ€™s numbers to the decimal. When output eclipses origin , culture becomes an empty promise. For years, organizations have treated culture as a marketing differentiator, not a moral compass. But culture isnâ€™t a campaign; itâ€™s an infrastructure. Itâ€™s the set of invisible systems that make truth either safe or expensive. The Workplace Renaissance We are in what I call a Workplace Renaissance â€” a collective awakening. People are realizing that the infrastructures we built decades ago are no longer good enough. The cracks we see in institutions, from government to consulting to tech, arenâ€™t random. Theyâ€™re revealing what happens when speed, scale, and status become more sacred than substance. A future-ready culture isnâ€™t about innovation alone. Itâ€™s about ethical architecture, building organizations on a human foundation, where accountability is not punishment but practice. People spend most of their waking hours at work. If we can fix culture there, the systems of communication, care, and clarity. We can ripple that repair across entire societies. The Five Things Leaders Must Do Next Start with cultural infrastructure, not slogans. Culture isnâ€™t a set of values painted on walls; itâ€™s the operating system that runs your decisions. Audit your systems, not just your sentiment. Make integrity a measurable deliverable. Require every team to embed verification processes, transparent sourcing, and explicit AI disclosure. Treat accuracy as a KPI. Empower psychological safety with clarity, not comfort. People should be able to flag risk without fear, but also know exactly how to escalate. Safety doesnâ€™t mean endless discussion; it means clear permission to speak the truth. Adopt micro-data and micro-learning loops. Replace quarterly retrospectives with short, frequent check-ins. Measure behavior in small doses â€” what worked this week, what broke, what needs recalibration. Work with firms that have a conscience, not just credentials. If youâ€™re outsourcing culture, hire consultants who live the principles they preach. Ask them: how do you handle mistakes? How do you ensure integrity internally? How do you hold yourselves accountable? A Call to Reckoning Just because youâ€™re a household name doesnâ€™t mean youâ€™re exempt from responsibility. In fact, legacy firms should be the gold standard for accountability. And yet, here we are â€” governments refunding contracts, employees burning out, and the public losing faith in the very institutions designed to guide them. So before you hire the next big name, ask yourself: 1. Do you actually get what you think youâ€™re paying for? 2. Do you see transformation, or just templates? 3. Are your consultants changing your system â€” or performing inside it? Because culture, at its core, is not what you say you believe. It could have been one team, one region, one oversight. But the question worth asking is: Why did this happen even once? What systems of accountability allowed it to? And more importantly, what kind of cultural environment makes professionals so rushed, so pressured, or so desensitized that integrity slips by unnoticed?","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":150,"end":180,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_12":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_12","name":"5c5d","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Psychological Safety Isnâ€™t Just a Buzzword","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_13":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_13","name":"b14e","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"In theory, consulting firms talk about â€œpsychological safety.â€ In practice, itâ€™s often the first casualty of a deadline. When people feel they canâ€™t question authority or push back against unrealistic timelines, thatâ€™s not psychological safety ; thatâ€™s quiet compliance.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_14":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_14","name":"1554","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Letâ€™s imagine a hypothetical moment:\n A junior analyst raises a concern, â€œI canâ€™t find a source for this citation. Should we leave it out?â€ A manager replies, â€œJust keep it moving. Weâ€™re already late.â€","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_15":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_15","name":"5278","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"That moment, the instant when someone chooses convenience over correctness , is where culture reveals itself. Itâ€™s not malice. Itâ€™s momentum. And when momentum outruns integrity, failure becomes inevitable.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_16":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_16","name":"ace3","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"When Values Become Performance","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_17":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_17","name":"a09b","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Iâ€™ve watched consulting firms betray the very values they sell. Many of them are sincere people trapped in systems optimized for optics. â€œIntegrityâ€ becomes a brand attribute, not a behavior. â€œAccountabilityâ€ becomes a slide deck, not a standard.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_18":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_18","name":"7c0a","type":"BQ","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Iâ€™ve met leaders who couldnâ€™t recite their companyâ€™s mission but could tell you last quarterâ€™s numbers to the decimal. When output eclipses origin, culture becomes an empty promise.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":124,"end":130,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":140,"end":146,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_19":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_19","name":"e912","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"For years, organizations have treated culture as a marketing differentiator, not a moral compass. But culture isnâ€™t a campaign; itâ€™s an infrastructure. Itâ€™s the set of invisible systems that make truth either safe or expensive.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_20":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_20","name":"bdf8","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Workplace Renaissance","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_21":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_21","name":"e3e5","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"We are in what I call a Workplace Renaissance â€” a collective awakening. People are realizing that the infrastructures we built decades ago are no longer good enough. The cracks we see in institutions, from government to consulting to tech, arenâ€™t random. Theyâ€™re revealing what happens when speed, scale, and status become more sacred than substance.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":24,"end":45,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_22":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_22","name":"314d","type":"BQ","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"A future-ready culture isnâ€™t about innovation alone. Itâ€™s about ethical architecture, building organizations on a human foundation, where accountability is not punishment but practice.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":64,"end":86,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":2,"end":14,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_23":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_23","name":"5095","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"People spend most of their waking hours at work. If we can fix culture there, the systems of communication, care, and clarity. We can ripple that repair across entire societies.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_24":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_24","name":"0bf2","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"The Five Things Leaders Must Do Next","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_25":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_25","name":"1f4f","type":"OLI","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Start with cultural infrastructure, not slogans.\n Culture isnâ€™t a set of values painted on walls; itâ€™s the operating system that runs your decisions. Audit your systems, not just your sentiment.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":0,"end":48,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_26":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_26","name":"91c9","type":"OLI","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Make integrity a measurable deliverable.\n Require every team to embed verification processes, transparent sourcing, and explicit AI disclosure. Treat accuracy as a KPI.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":0,"end":40,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_27":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_27","name":"1238","type":"OLI","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Empower psychological safety with clarity, not comfort.\n People should be able to flag risk without fear, but also know exactly how to escalate. Safety doesnâ€™t mean endless discussion; it means clear permission to speak the truth.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":0,"end":55,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":128,"end":131,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_28":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_28","name":"08f9","type":"OLI","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Adopt micro-data and micro-learning loops.\n Replace quarterly retrospectives with short, frequent check-ins. Measure behavior in small doses â€” what worked this week, what broke, what needs recalibration.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":0,"end":42,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_29":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_29","name":"90aa","type":"OLI","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Work with firms that have a conscience, not just credentials.\n If youâ€™re outsourcing culture, hire consultants who live the principles they preach. Ask them: how do you handle mistakes? How do you ensure integrity internally? How do you hold yourselves accountable?","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"STRONG","start":0,"end":61,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null},{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":242,"end":252,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_30":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_30","name":"c179","type":"H3","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"A Call to Reckoning","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_31":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_31","name":"4e81","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Just because youâ€™re a household name doesnâ€™t mean youâ€™re exempt from responsibility. In fact, legacy firms should be the gold standard for accountability.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":121,"end":134,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_32":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_32","name":"456a","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"And yet, here we are â€” governments refunding contracts, employees burning out, and the public losing faith in the very institutions designed to guide them.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_33":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_33","name":"1652","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"So before you hire the next big name, ask yourself:\n1. Do you actually get what you think youâ€™re paying for?","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_34":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_34","name":"b860","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"2. Do you see transformation, or just templates?","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_35":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_35","name":"8283","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"3. Are your consultants changing your system â€” or performing inside it?","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_36":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_36","name":"5a32","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"Because culture, at its core, is not what you say you believe. Itâ€™s what youâ€™re willing to hold accountable when no oneâ€™s watching.","hasDropCap":null,"dropCapImage":null,"markups":[{"__typename":"Markup","type":"EM","start":46,"end":49,"href":null,"anchorType":null,"userId":null,"linkMetadata":null}],"codeBlockMetadata":null,"iframe":null,"mixtapeMetadata":null},"Paragraph:2b7f60622eb2_37":{"__typename":"Paragraph","id":"2b7f60622eb2_37","name":"f505","type":"P","href":null,"layout":null,"metadata":null,"text":"If you liked this article, share it with someone shaping the future of work.\n True People Consulting helps organizations build breathable, high-performing systems that align people, purpose, and practice. The 5 Pillars of Cultural Health Every Leader Needs to Build a Thriving Workplace From clarity to accountability, these five pillars form the invisible architecture that drives trust, performance, and lasting change. Samantha Truman Sep 18, 2025 Share Most organizations treat culture like an afterthoughtâ€”something you fix with perks, slogans, or an offsite. But culture isnâ€™t a side project. Itâ€™s the system that determines whether strategy sticks, people thrive, and performance endures. Photo by ian dooley on Unsplash Through my work, Iâ€™ve seen the same pattern again and again: companies may dabble in one or two aspects of cultural health, but very few invest in all five. Thatâ€™s why change feels impossible to sustain. So what does true cultural health require? 1. Strategic Clarity & Alignment The organization holds a shared, concrete picture of where itâ€™s going. People can trace their day-to-day work to strategy, KPIs, and outcomesâ€”so priorities and trade-offs are explicit. Without this alignment, employees spend their days guessing, projects sprawl, and leaders confuse busyness with progress. 2. Cohesion & Psychological Safety Communication is consistent, candid, and respectful across teams. People are supported and can speak up, take risks, and show up as themselves without fear of blame or exclusion. When psychological safety collapses, innovation collapses with it. Silence and fear become the real culture. 3. Technology Experience & Empowerment Tools and systems are accessible, equitable, and matched to how this culture actually works. They remove friction and empower people to do their best work with confidence. The best tech isnâ€™t the flashiestâ€”itâ€™s the one that integrates seamlessly into the way people actually collaborate. 4. Change Agility & Leadership Enablement The organization adapts quickly and learns out loud. Leaders create trust, clarity, and capacity during uncertaintyâ€”equipping people to navigate change rather than endure it. Resilience doesnâ€™t come from slogans. It comes from leaders modeling vulnerability and courage when the ground shifts. 5. Accountability & Performance Integrity Expectations are clear, commitments are kept, and feedback is timely. Performance conversations and recognition are fair, consistent, and aligned to values and results. Accountability without integrity breeds fear. Integrity without accountability breeds drift. Healthy cultures hold both, tightly. Why It Matters Cultural health isnâ€™t optional. Itâ€™s the infrastructure that holds strategy, performance, and trust together. Companies that only invest in one or two pillars may see short-term winsâ€”but the system eventually buckles. The organizations that will thrive into 2030 are those that see cultural health as strategy, not decoration. ðŸ‘‰ This article is part of my ongoing series on cultural health and the future of work. If you want more essays, frameworks, and stories from inside the culture shift, please subscribe. Or connect with me on LinkedIn to keep the conversation going. Workplace\",\"type\":\"newsletter\",\"video_upload_id\":null,\"write_comment_permissions\":\"everyone\",\"meter_type\":\"none\",\"live_stream_id\":null,\"is_published\":true,\"restacks\":0,\"reactions\":{\"\u2764\":0},\"top_exclusions\":[],\"pins\":[],\"section_pins\":[],\"has_shareable_clips\":false,\"previous_post_slug\":\"when-silence-speaks-how-cracked-culture\",\"next_post_slug\":\"why-leaders-miss-the-88-trillion\",\"cover_image\":\"https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1497032628192-86f99bcd76bc?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wzMDAzMzh8MHwxfHNlYXJjaHw5fHx3b3JrfGVufDB8fHx8MTc1ODEzMDE4OHww&ixlib=rb-4.1.0&q=80&w=1080\",\"cover_image_is_square\":false,\"cover_image_is_explicit\":false,\"videoUpload\":null,\"podcastFields\":{\"post_id\":173193012,\"podcast_episode_number\":null,\"podcast_season_number\":null,\"podcast_episode_type\":null,\"should_syndicate_to_other_feed\":null,\"syndicate_to_section_id\":null,\"hide_from_feed\":false,\"free_podcast_url\":null,\"free_podcast_duration\":null},\"podcastUpload\":null,\"podcastPreviewUpload\":null,\"voiceover_upload_id\":null,\"voiceoverUpload\":null,\"has_voiceover\":false,\"description\":\"From clarity to accountability, these five pillars form the invisible architecture that drives trust, performance, and lasting change.\",\"body_html\":\" Most organizations treat culture like an afterthought\u2014something you fix with perks, slogans, or an offsite. But culture isn\u2019t a side project. It\u2019s the system that determines whether strategy sticks, people thrive, and performance endures. Photo by ian dooley on Unsplash Through my work, I\u2019ve seen the same pattern again and again: companies may dabble in one or two aspects of cultural health, but very few invest in all five. That\u2019s why change feels impossible to sustain. So what does true cultural health require? 1. Strategic Clarity & Alignment The organization holds a shared, concrete picture of where it\u2019s going. People can trace their day-to-day work to strategy, KPIs, and outcomes\u2014so priorities and trade-offs are explicit. Without this alignment, employees spend their days guessing, projects sprawl, and leaders confuse busyness with progress. 2. Cohesion & Psychological Safety Communication is consistent, candid, and respectful across teams. People are supported and can speak up, take risks, and show up as themselves without fear of blame or exclusion. When psychological safety collapses, innovation collapses with it. Silence and fear become the real culture. 3. Technology Experience & Empowerment Tools and systems are accessible, equitable, and matched to how this culture actually works. They remove friction and empower people to do their best work with confidence. The best tech isn\u2019t the flashiest\u2014it\u2019s the one that integrates seamlessly into the way people actually collaborate. 4. Change Agility & Leadership Enablement The organization adapts quickly and learns out loud. Leaders create trust, clarity, and capacity during uncertainty\u2014equipping people to navigate change rather than endure it. Resilience doesn\u2019t come from slogans. It comes from leaders modeling vulnerability and courage when the ground shifts. 5. Accountability & Performance Integrity Expectations are clear, commitments are kept, and feedback is timely. Performance conversations and recognition are fair, consistent, and aligned to values and results. Accountability without integrity breeds fear. Integrity without accountability breeds drift. Healthy cultures hold both, tightly. Why It Matters Cultural health isn\u2019t optional. It\u2019s the infrastructure that holds strategy, performance, and trust together. Companies that only invest in one or two pillars may see short-term wins\u2014but the system eventually buckles. The organizations that will thrive into 2030 are those that see cultural health as strategy, not decoration. \uD83D\uDC49 This article is part of my ongoing series on cultural health and the future of work. If you want more essays, frameworks, and stories from inside the culture shift, please subscribe. Or connect with me on LinkedIn to keep the conversation going. \",\"truncated_body_text\":\"Most organizations treat culture like an afterthought\u2014something you fix with perks, slogans, or an offsite. title: Ideal Customer Profile
content: True People Consulting targets mid to large organizations (500-10,000+ employees) seeking culture transformation, leadership development, and organizational effectiveness consulting. Key decision makers: CHRO, VP HR, Chief People Officers, CEOs focused on culture change.

title: Success Stories & Results
content: Helped Fortune 500 companies reduce turnover by 40%, improved employee engagement scores by 35%, successfully managed post-merger culture integration for 10,000+ employee organizations, transformed toxic cultures into high-performing teams.

Sign in Medium Logo Write Search Sign up Sign in Mastodon Politics of Health Equity: The Price of Silence Samantha Truman 5 min read Â· Jun 6, 2025 -- Listen Share By Samantha Truman Right now, millions are being dropped from Medicaid rolls. Food insecurity is rising, leaving families without consistent access to fresh, nutritious meals. Community hospitals are closing, severing vital lifelines in already underserved regions. Yet some still politicize equity, treating it as a threat rather than the foundation of a just healthcare system. But to me, health equity isnâ€™t political. Itâ€™s personal. A Tale of a Few Cities Before I was a healthcare leader, I was a 19-year-old trying to survive in a system never designed for people like me. Born in Ukraine, raised in Jamaica, and shaped by a stepfather from Palestine, my life gave me a deeply global and intersectional perspective on health and justice. Each place revealed how identity, politics, and history decide who gets care â€” and who doesnâ€™t. Press enter or click to view image in full size In Ukraine, I was born into a post-Soviet health system marked by scarcity, where underfunded institutions struggled to meet basic needs. In Jamaica, I witnessed how colonial legacies and chronic underinvestment led to shortages and a brain drain as healthcare workers left seeking stability. Through my stepfatherâ€™s Palestinian heritage, I learned health is not just clinical care â€” it is a human right, one threatened daily by occupation, displacement, and systemic violence. These experiences root my commitment to health equity as a global imperative â€” one demanding structural change and deep cultural humility. From Survival to Awareness As a teenager, my family moved to California, where my immigrant parents â€” skilled professionals abroad â€” struggled to find work that reflected their expertise. From 14, I saw how hard it was to start over in a system that didnâ€™t recognize our worth. We were poor. My parents were often sick. It fell to me to find a way forward. At 19, I landed a job at a multinational logistics company earning $12.50 an hour, just 50 cents more than my previous banking job. That small raise allowed me to leave a friendâ€™s couch in San Bernardino and rent a cramped 200-square-foot studio in Chula Vista, a working-class border community. From my door, I could see the Mexican flag waving in the wind. Some nights, staring at it, Iâ€™d wonder what happens next. By day, I worked in La Jolla â€” an upscale enclave with boutique cafes, luxury cars, and oceanfront mansions. People there moved differently. They smiled more, lived longer, bought fresh food without a second thought. Back in Chula Vista, I rationed food and gas. I survived mostly on baked potatoes, sometimes with butter and cheese if I was lucky. I breathed in pollution, battled roaches, and pushed through fatigue. At 19, I didnâ€™t understand why I felt so worn down. Now, I know: I was living the embodied toll of inequality. The Physical Toll of Inequality Pelvic pain from heavy lifting turned into a hairline fracture, then a full one. Signs of hypertension were missed for years, eventually leading to heart issues. These werenâ€™t isolated health events â€” they were consequences of working-class precarity, food insecurity, and stress. Whenever I walked through La Jolla or visited a Whole Foods, I felt a sharp contrast. Their health was supported by environment and access. Mine was deteriorating from deprivation. I didnâ€™t know about social programs that couldâ€™ve helped. I wasnâ€™t aware of how deeply the places we live, work, and grow shape our health. If I could go back, Iâ€™d want that knowledge early â€” because education couldâ€™ve made my path easier. The Cost of Inequality â€” Locally and Globally What I experienced was more than poverty. It was a textbook example of how social determinants of health shape up to 80% of health outcomes, according to the CDC. And this reality is not confined to the U.S. In Jamaica , underfunded systems, medical shortages, and climate change strain already fragile infrastructure. In Ukraine , just before the 2022 invasion, my parents received exceptional post-operative care. But war has turned healthcare into a humanitarian crisis â€” interrupting treatments, displacing providers, and making care increasingly unaffordable. My grandmother, living on a $50 monthly pension, now faces soaring medical costs she cannot pay. In Gaza , the health system is collapsing under siege. Hospitals have been bombed, doctors killed, and access to food, water, and care deliberately blocked. There is no neutrality in the destruction of healthcare. In all these places, injustice, violence, and economic constraint deepen inequities. These are not isolated crises. They are global echoes of systemic failure. Closer to home, in California, Chula Vista had been redlined for decades, starved of investment. It remains a food desert, with poor housing and limited care. Just 20 miles away, La Jolla flourishes. The difference between these zip codes isnâ€™t just income â€” itâ€™s life expectancy. In California, people in wealthier neighborhoods live 10 to 15 years longer than those in historically disinvested ones. Equity Is Not Up for Debate Despite overwhelming evidence, health equity faces fierce political attack. What was once a moral and public health imperative is now dismissed as divisive. But acknowledging the disproportionate harm faced by marginalized communities isnâ€™t controversial â€” itâ€™s responsible. Research shows that chronic exposure to racism, poverty, and instability â€” what scholars call â€œweatheringâ€ â€” leads to early chronic illness, higher hypertension, and increased maternal mortality. Yet across the country, there are efforts to erase these truths. Public health agencies are pressured to remove â€œequityâ€ from strategic plans. DEI programs are being dismantled. Some states have banned DEI language entirely. Over 20 million people risk losing Medicaid coverage due to rollbacks â€” harming Black, Brown, and low-income communities most. And Black women remain three times more likely than white women to die from pregnancy-related causes, regardless of income or education. These are not abstract debates. They are life-and-death decisions about who is seen, who is cared for, and who survives. The Foundation of a Just Healthcare System Health equity is not charity. Itâ€™s not a luxury. Itâ€™s the foundation of a functioning healthcare system. When everyone has access to preventive care, fresh food, clean air, and stable housing, society benefits. Life expectancy improves. Productivity rises. Healthcare costs fall. Solutions exist: â€“ Expand Medicaid access â€“ Invest in culturally competent care â€“ Reverse redlining through community development â€“ Protect DEI initiatives in health institutions These are practical, evidence-based steps toward fairness. The Urgency of Now The question isnâ€™t whether health equity matters. Itâ€™s whether we have the courage to fight for it. Will we listen to communities in crisis? Will we protect policies that guarantee fair access to care? I know the road ahead will be hard. But I also know this: I will not be silent . To every policymaker, healthcare leader, advocate, and organizer: I invite you to stand with me. Because until every person, in every country, can live a healthy life, our work is far from over.
